The contrast just pointed out is <s>of such<\s> so
general that when an observer finds it difficult
to distinguish between planes of cleavage & strati
fication, as sometimes happens where either or
both sets of planes are obscure, he will generally
<s>find that<\s> be right in <s>regarding as<\s> referring to bedding those
planes whose inclination diminishes in receding
from the axis of elevation & to cleavage those
which become steeper at a distance from the
axis. And a similar empirical rule will often assist us to distinguish <s>as<\s> foliation from
stratification. <s>The extreme complexity of<\s> <s>Another proof of the<\s> The contortions of Gneiss
& Mica Slate are also far more complex than are
ever found in the most disturbed strata & are
such as could only be produced in matter in a state
of at least, semi-fluidity; for they <s>contort<\s> are not
accompanied with any fractures across the layers of
rock such as are found in beds which have been bent after
their deposition. The materials of the foliated rocks
seem to have been in a <s>plastic<\s> state sufficiently
fluid to allow the mineral ingredients to separate
freely & arrange themselves according to their chemical
or crystalline affinities, & while that process
was going on to have been subjected to enormous
pressure along certain axes of elevation, which
